press.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: people who write reports for newspapers, radio, or television
press.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The press has been very nasty about him.
press.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: reports in newspapers and on radio and television
press.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: To judge from the press, the concert was a great success.
The band has received good press coverage (=the reports written about something in newspapers).
The story was widely covered in the national press.
press.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: a business that prints and sometimes also sells books
press.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a machine that prints books, newspapers, or magazines
press.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a piece of equipment used to put weight on something in order to make it flat or to force liquid out of it
press.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a light steady push against something small
press.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: a crowd of people pushing against each other
press.translation[0].note_box[0].section: There was very little about the incident in the national press.
Evening classes are advertised in the local press.
The British press have blamed other countries for North Sea pollution.
African countries want the foreign press to report African affairs.
The book received excellent reviews in the quality press.
He regularly appeared in the tabloid press alongside well-known actresses.
The gutter press enjoyed printing the sensational story.
I am glad that we have a free press in this country.
He is reluctant to talk to the press.
‘It was a really tough decision, ’ she told the press.
The confidential report was leaked to the press.
According to press reports, he was suffering from exhaustion.
The event received a lot of press coverage.
A group of press photographers was waiting for her outside.
press.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to push something firmly against a surface
press.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Manville kept his back pressed flat against the wall.
She pressed the gas pedal and the car leapt forwards.
He pressed a card into her hand before leaving.
press.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to push a button, switch etc to make a machine start, a bell ring etc
press.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Lily pressed the switch and plunged the room into darkness.
Press control, alt, delete to log on to the computer.
press.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to make clothes smooth using a hot iron
press.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: I’ll need to press my suit.
press.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to move in a particular direction by pushing
press.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: The car rocked as the crowd pressed hard against it.
press.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to try hard to persuade someone to do something, especially by asking them many times
press.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: I felt that if I had pressed him he would have lent me the money.
I was pressing my claim for custody of the child.
The police pressed her to remember all the details.
The manufacturers are pressing the government for action.
We must continue to press for full equality.
press.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: to put pressure or a weight on something to make it flat, crush it etc
press.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: At this stage the grapes have to be pressed.
press.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: to hold someone or something close to you
press.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: He reached out and pressed her to him.
press.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: to offer something to someone and try to make them take it
press.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: I pressed money on him, but he refused to take it.
press.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: to push a weight up from your chest using only your arms, without moving your legs or feet
press.translation[1].definitions[9].defi: to make a copy of a record, CD etc
press.translation[1].note_box[0].section: to push something down or against a surface with your fingers or foot
The doctor gently pressed her stomach.
To move forward, press the accelerator.
I pressed ‘delete’ and started again.
squeeze
to press something inwards from both sides
It’s one of those balls that make a funny noise when you squeeze it.
Squeeze the lemon and add the juice to the sauce.
squash
to press something against a surface accidentally and damage it by making it flat
Don’t squash the tomatoes.
He sat on my hat and squashed it.
crush
to press something very hard so that it breaks into very small pieces, or is very badly damaged
Crush two cloves of garlic.
The front of the car was completely crushed in the crash.
mash
to press cooked vegetables or fruit until they are soft and smooth
Mash the potatoes while they are warm.
Babies love mashed bananas.
grind
to press something solid until it becomes a powder, using a machine or tool
the machine that grinds the corn
freshly ground coffee
press.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: to try hard to persuade someone to do something
press.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Investor Harold Simmons is pressing to have the company’s annual meeting delayed.
Finance Ministry officials are pressing the brokerage houses to eliminate the problem.
The extension will give the union more time to press Chrysler to keep the plant open.
press.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: if someone presses a claim, demand etc, they continue trying to get it accepted
press.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: China is pressing its claim to the scattered territories, some of which have oil-drilling potential.
We will continue to press our case vigorously in the courts.
press.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to say officially that someone has done something illegal and must go to court
press.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: A Citicorp official said the bank would not be pressing charges.
The government is pressing a civil action to get the money from investors.
press.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: the people writing for the newspapers, radio, or television
press.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The judgement reflected badly on the press, including his own newspaper.
a meeting with the financial press
press.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: reports in the newspapers and on radio and television
press.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: a savage attack on the banking sector inthe local press reports.
Criticism from the investigation committee could lead to some unpleasant press coverage (=reports in the newspapers, on television etc).
The FBI has been getting a bad press lately  (=there have been a lot of reports criticizing it in the newspapers etc).
press.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: a business that prints and sometimes sells books
